newsitem.title: FRANCE: Arianespace board names Luton chairman.
newsitem.headline: Arianespace board names Luton chairman.

text.p: The board of European space group Arianespace said on Friday it planned to name Jean-Marie Luton as chairman to replace Charles Bigot from July 1.
The organisation charged Luton with preparing a profound study on a European space transport system and make detailed proposals before April 1998.
The board decided to end the contract with managing director Francis Avanzi, who had beeen hired in January 1996 with an eye to succeeding Bigot, 65, as chairman.
Luton, a former head of the European Space Agency (ESA), had already been named head of holding group Ariannespace Participation on April 17.

The board will ask a general meeting of shareholders on June 16 to name Luton as head of the Arianespace SA company which commercialises the Ariane rockets, using the Kourou launching site in French Guiana.

Luton's appointment follows a power struggle among the company shareholders, with the French government backing Luton in order to get a strong European agency capable of taking on competition by merged U.S. giants.
Avanzi, a former head of aeroengine company CFM International, had been hired by Bigot himself as heir apparent.
French interests control 55 percent of Arianespace shares, with the space study centre CNES having 32 percent.
Germany holds 18.5 percent and Italy 8.11 percent while other shareholders are mainly within the European Union.
In a statement, Arianespace's board said that Avanzi, 43, had done "excellent work" and that the decision to name Luton was "independent of his own qualities which are unanimously recognised."
Luton, 55, has been head of the 14 nation ESA since 1990. Before that he has been at CNES and Aerospatiale.
Arianespace, which controls more than half of the world's commercial satellite launch market, faces strong competition from the planned purchase of McDonnell Douglas Corp by Boeing Co.
Arianespace is set to re-try launching its newest Ariane-5 rocket after a previous trial ended a few minutes after launch in an explosion.
